head.title: Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. - Page #7

body.p: << First Page | < Previous Page | Page #7 of 32 | Next Page > | Last Page >>

td.p: Umfreville, Edward. Journal of a Passage in a Canoe from Pais Plat in Lake Superior to Portage de l'Isle in River Ouinipique, 1784. An electronic transcription. MFTP #0030

div.p: paymt here, & were desirous to leave us, but I was resolv'd to deny this to the last 'till their agreemt was compleated; they tried sevl Indian fetches to raize a drink, but as they found we we determin'd to keep our word, they consented to accompany us. We made some small presents to a few left behind & proceeded on a Course NWbN. between 2 islands which appear from ye end of the Portage 14m. to a point. Before this Co was compleated we met a family of Ind[s] in 2 Canoes: the man remember'd Seeing me at Severn Fort on the Coast of Hudson's Bay, he belongs to Sturgeon Lake, & has agreed to Pilot us to Portage de l'Isle, proceeded with him a few miles when we we Stop'd by Thunder, Wind & Rain. He pretends he has a Son hereabouts whom he must see before he can go with us, he proposes to set off To-morrow morning & return abt 2 o'clock. We parted Co with our first Guides entirely satisfied with each other.

June 21 Monday. Sevl Inds came to us yesterday afternoon, which proved very rainy & Stormy, with thunder & lightening. The Inds were very troublesome for a drink, a little of which was given them. Our guide told us flatly this morng he would not go with us, but on our setting off with another he soon follow'd us. Proceeded from the point mentd yesterday across a Bay NNW3m. then NWbN to a pt across another Bay 4m. but instead of crossing it entirely we turn'd round a point in the middle of it, this leads into an opening like a river – 1st Co in it is WSW1½m. then WbN1m. WNW1m. which opens into ye Lake, then Wt 3m. to ye No end of the 1st isld which appears from the So shore – then WbN6m. between sevl islands to a rocky point – here we slept[.] It is necessary to remark, that a young Guide ought to be provided with a compass in this Lake, as it is full of islds wch form as many openings[.]

22 Tuesday. This day it blew so hard Wtly that we could not proceed. The men were employ'd putting the Canoe in better trim for the Carrying places: the ribs & Timbers were all taken out, washed & made smaller, so that now she is considerably lighter. The guide is very wavering in his opinion, he this day told us he must be oblig'd to leave us on Acct of his wife's sickness, tho' she was equally bad when he first engg engag'd. Every reasonable promise is made him to persuade him to continue the Journey; but Inds will be Inds to the last of the Chapter. We tried to fish in the Lac, but the mesh[ing] of the nets are too large.

23 Wednesday. From the rocky point mentd yesterday the day before yesterday, we proceeded WNW. to the So end of an isld 2½m. at the end of which lays a small rocky island a short distance off, went between them then NW1m. to ye point of an isld – then NWbW3m. to the pt of another isld of high land, coast along the end of this isld 1½m. NW – then to a point across a Bay NWbN[6m.]

td.p:

in lavender , modifications made by the assumed author(s).
